title: On the logical skills of large language models: evaluations using arbitrarily complex first-order logic problems
author: Shokhrukh Ibragimov (University of Münster), Arnulf Jentzen (The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen), Benno Kuckuck (University of Münster), ...
relevance_why: The methodologies for evaluating logical reasoning in large language models can inform approaches for audio captioning models, especially in understanding complexities in logic-based reasoning.
background: Evaluating the performance of large language models on first-order logic problems to determine their reasoning capabilities.
contribution: This paper introduces a method for generating first-order logic statements to create datasets for evaluating the logical reasoning of language models, demonstrating varying complexity in problem-solving.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing evaluations often focus on memorization rather than reasoning capabilities.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work generates problems at arbitrarily high complexity and evaluates models based on their logical reasoning performance.

key_innovation: The method of generating complex first-order logic statements that require planning and reasoning rather than mere factual recall.
real_world_impact: Improving the evaluation benchmarks for language models can have broad implications for their applicability in critical reasoning tasks in various domains.
limitations: No limitations explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.first-order logic: **First-order logic** is a formal logical system used to express statements about objects and their relationships, facilitating reasoning in mathematical and computational domains.
new_terms.Zermelo\u2013Fraenkel set theory: **Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory** is a foundational system for mathematics that describes sets and their relations, serving as a basis for most of modern mathematical logic.

open_sourcing: All datasets and code used for generating them, along with data from evaluations, are publicly available at https://github.com/bkuckuck/logical-skills-of-llms.
